discussion.content: FUS: Field Upgrade Software. Therefore, the Console is the answer.
Console access to the WLC during the upgrade process is not required. However it is recommended that you have console access so that you can monitor the progress of the process.

questions.question_text: An engineer has been asked to upgrade the FUS on the Wireless LAN controller. How can they monitor the status of the upgrade?

A controller is connected to a Cisco Catalyst switch. The switch port configuration looks like this: interface GigabitEthernet 1/0/10 switchport switchport trunk encapsulation dot1q switchport trunk allowed vlan 1,20,30,50 switchport trunk native vlan 20 switchport mode trunk
Which controller CLI command assigns its management interface to the native VLAN interface of the Cisco Catalyst switch?

discussion.content:
I think both B and C are correct.
You must enable management via wireless to use a wireless client for management, because it is disabled by default in the WLC.

But once you enable it, you still are not able to download / upload the configuration through a wireless client. But I think the key term is "All" management tasks. There must be something else you cannot do from a wireless client.

questions.question_text: Which type of management tasks can be completed on a Cisco WLC remotely from a wireless client?

choices.D: The default configuration of the Cisco WLC allows only CLI access and then only the use of show commands, so no configuration is possible.
choices.C: In the default configuration, no management or configuration is possible through the GUI on the Cisco WLS.
choices.A: All management and configuration tasks can be performed from a wireless client except for using debug commands.
choices.B: All management and configuration tasks, except uploads from and downloads to the Cisco WLC, are permitted.

discussion.content:
I think that the correct answer is D.
If you want to implement a enterprise WLAN solution you need the same number of autonomous and cloud APs, the diffence is that in a cloud-based architecture the AP management function is pushed out of the enterprise and into the Internet cloud.

Agree, autonomous != enterprise.

D for me.
Should this not be D Cloud?

comments.content: That's a good point. In enterprise solutions we 100% need more than just autonomous APs, so we need at least 1 WLC. Using Meraki solutions we can use the "cloud controller", so it would be less hardware units onsite. I will go with D either.

questions.question_text: A client wants to implement an enterprise WLAN solution with the minimum hardware deployed onsite. What solution fulfills this requirement?
If an antenna has a dBd of 8.6, what is the dBi value?
